Another history tidbit. Georg Cantor was working on trigonometric (i.e., Fourier) series when he found the need to find a way to characterize those real-number collections upon which given series would converge/diverge. This analysis led him to invent Set Theory.

If I remember the history correctly, the Fourier series idea was first suggested by Daniel Bernoulli (son of Johann and nephew of Jakob. Euler's father and Johann had both roomed in Jakob's house in Basel when the father and Johann were both students at the University of Basel when Jakob taught.  -- Daniel is the Bernoulli of "Bernoulli's Principle" in fluid flow). He was studying it in connection with not the Heat Equation, but the Wave Equation as a model for a plucked string (like a guitar string). He proposed in a letter to Euler that any realistic initial configuration could be written as a sum of sine waves. Euler replied both showing how the coefficients of the sine terms could be calculated, but also criticizing the concept. He noted that a simple initial configuration would be pulling the string out at the middle, giving the string (endpoints fixed) a v-shape. That shape is not differentiable at the vertex, but all sine functions used in the proposed sum are differentiable everywhere. So, he stated, the idea could not work in the generality that Daniel suggested. The idea was out. When Fourier first presented his results in a paper of heat propagation to a Paris committee in 1807, the paper was rejected. On of the committee members, Joseph Lagrange (a protégé of the now-dead Euler) specifically criticized the notion that any function could be represented by Fourier's trigonometric series.

23:35 Is there a mistake in the hint?
" cn = (an/2) + (bn/2).i " doesn't work (as long as cn with n > 0 belongs to counterclockwise rotation as in the video)

Correction: " cn = (an/2) - (bn/2).i " with the "-" instead of the "+" you get the right expression.

A simple example for illustration:
2.cos(x) + 3.sin(x) = real( (2-3i).exp(ix) ) = real( (2+3i).exp(-ix) ) ...but "real( (2+3i).exp(ix) )" is NOT the same ("-" is missing)!

While the final result through the summation of the rotating components is a beautiful trajectory, the trajectory of each individual integral to produce each component is just as beautiful. I did all this when I wrote a paper on "The Hidden wonders of Laplace and the Convolution function" in 3-Dimensions. It is all a recognition function where one can recognize the magnitude and rotating sequence of an unknown helix by multiplying it with a unit helix of the same frequency but rotating in the opposite direction. All this is described at 18:32. That particular integral is a straight line but all the other complex 3-D integrals all have their own beauty.

Since Keplerian ellipses can also be accurately described in terms of Fourier's epicycles, is it only a commitment to Occam's razor that has us describe planets as really moving in ellipses? Since Kepler's laws can be derived from Newton's with their built in physically implausible (but exquisitely useful)  infinite speed of causation and absolute time and space, on what basis  are Ptolemy's epicycles less compelling models for physical reality? Circa 1:30, you mention we can draw whatever we want with a Fourier transform "chain". What about drawing two vanishing point spirals? A single Fourier chain would get non-halting frozen in the first vanishing point and it'd never start drawing the second vanishing point. In other words, we can't draw multiple Infinite recursions using a Fourier chain's single recursive Infinity potential. However, we could use multiple Fourier chains in tandem to draw multiple vanishing points; one chain per vanishing point (chain branching).

Years ago I invented a symbol for e^(2πi). It's a 1 with a squiggle through it. It cant' be done in Youtube comment text format. But never mind. e^(2πi) = 1, so that makes sense. Put in "nt" as in e^(2πint) is written as (1~)^(nt). Of course, 1^(nt) = 1 which is boring, but the 1~ symbol hints to take not the principal root but the "next" one. Makes Fourier math a lot easier to write, and is especially good for RF and microwave electronics analysis, and acoustics, and anything wavy.


I wrote about this in a blog, https://wigglewave.wordpress.com/2016/10/23/one-tilde-a-new-symbol-for-wavy-math/ with an image of the symbol.

16:30-20:10 It is worth noting that the process of extracting value of c_n is much like doing dot product. Taking dot product of a vector (x,y,z) with (1,0,0) extracts the value x. The vector (x,y,z) is an analog of the function f(t), (1,0,0) is an analog of e^(-n 2 pi t), and dot product is an analog of multiplication of f(t) by e^(-n 2 pi t) and then take integral, extracting the value x is an analog of extracting the value c_n.

I have a question about this that I don't know how to ask, because I'm not entirely sure what, exactly the question is that I mean to ask. But, essentially, I'll preface it with this: I make music, so I know about the fourier series in terms of music and harmonics, and, more specifically, for my question, squarewaves as the sound for music (generally electronic music). Now, I know that the standard squarewave is an approximation made from all the odd valued frequencies with amplitudes at one over that frequency value (to put it in, probably, mathematically incorrect terms). But this waveform that this produces contains a whole lot of wobbliness, especially at the sides of the square, where there are notable spikes. This probably isn't a problem in most applications of the fourier series, but with music, that inaccuracy and those sharp spikes are audible. I've done some experimenting and found that the frequencies can be added together with a different amplitude shift, and it produces what looks like a much better approximation of a square wave, albeit on that approaches a true square wave probably more slowly, I think.

So, while you show a typical squarewave here, and with the program I used, it would be this:
https://i.imgur.com/yvkhiAB.png

Here's what I came up with (animated): https://i.imgur.com/qm92B0C.gif

The basic idea (although this program isn't prefect, so I had to estimate) is that the slope of the waveform only changes from increasing to decreasing, or vice versa, at the peaks and troughs, and nowhere else, and also the amplitudes of each frequency, given that constraint, are at their maximum possible value ('cause otherwise, you'd get something closer to a regular sine wave, obviously). And I was able to listen to this waveform and compare it to the standard squarewave, and this one sounds much nicer. It isn't anywhere near as harsh or buzzing. But I guess, what I want to know is what have I stumbled upon, and is there some mathematics behind it that's interesting, and how does this process of approximating a squarewave work, and is there a formula for this? Basically, I'm curious as to why we don't use this method of approximation instead, because it looks like it is a much better method of approximation (even though, I suppose the standard method is probably easier, and, on average, despite being so wavy, approximates it more quickly). Anyway. This has been on my mind for probably over a year now. I'd be grateful and intrigued to learn anything about what I stumbled upon here.

Also, would whatever mathematics is behind this concept help to trace more aesthetically pleasing images with less wobbly lines?

Fun Fact: This is why Ptolemy’s idea of epicycles worked. Basically he thought that all the planets revolved around the earth, but perfect circles didn’t match up with observations. However, when the planets happened to go in a smaller circle along their orbit, an “epicycles”, he could make it fit closer to reality. By tuning his epicycles he got a more accurate result that beat out Copernicus until he added epicycles to his model. It was only until Kepler realized that epicycles were just approximations to ellipses that we figured it out.

Some intuitions I used to have, and still have, about Fourier Transforms:
●Our computers collect data from sensors and memory storage by binary system wich is a variant of Tylor transform : Decomposition of any function into polynomials, in the case of binary computing the polynomials are exclusively power of 2.
●On the other hand, Biological sensors ( Our eyes, ears, ...),collect and process information by decomposition into Fourier transforms, that's why the brain can recognize voices , faces and handwriting. Using FT is a natural technique Artificial Intelligence can explore to step away from Robotic stage

I don't want to be nitpicking, but the way you describe convergence for a function doesn't actually apply to the Fourier series of the step function.

In that case I think it's more of a L2 convergence where the L2 norm of the step function minus your partial sum is arbitrarily close to 0.

I'm not sure though, correct me if I'm wrong. But the fact that you get those weird non converging peaks near 0 is typical of discontinuous functions and indicates that it's not a convergence in the usual sense.

Grant, I don't know if you hold a graduate degree yet, but with the talent you've got and the mindset about education you have right now I think you should seriously consider applying for funding/grants to fund your teaching endeavors. Not because you need to increase the quality of your content (definitely not the case), but because your material is reaching the level of becoming an international reference for dissemination of undergraduate and graduate-level mathematics.

Your material makes me remember of Ascher Shapiro's 1961 fluid mechanics series (National Committee for Fluid Mechanics Films [http://web.mit.edu/hml/ncfmf.html]). Back then obviously the animations were crude due to the technology available, but the way complex fluid mechanics concepts were taught is so beautifully intuitive that it keeps on having a great impact even today, more than 60 years later. It is actually used as graduate course material for many institutions (including the one I'm a graduate student right now). Your material already supersedes the quality of Shapiro's work both in technological refinement and level of insight provided, at least in my opinion.

I'm not sure how ambitious you are about this project, Grant, but you should definitely step up from the Youtube "every-man-for-himself" fight against "the Algorithm" to something actually professional that can support your work long-term and be of greater impact. You don't need to stop publishing on Youtube, but having a funding source will definitely afford you a few fellow content producers so you can focus on the aspects that really make the content stand out (i.e., the story, the insight, the animation standard) and free some of your time from the details (making the animation programs work, rendering/editing, etc). I'm absolutely sure that your content to-do list increases at a faster pace than you can animate it right now and having people to work with you would increase your impact even more. I already commented in the past, your work is part of a revolution on how knowledge is disseminated in the modern "information" age!

I like the linear algebra/functional analysis viewpoint of Fourier series: "Nice" functions [0,1]->R form a real vector space with an inner product on it given by <f,g>=integral from 0 to 1 of f(x)*(conjugation of g(x))dx. One can see that the functions of the form e^(2*i*pi*k*x) are a system of normed orthogonal vectors in this. The inner product <f,e^(2*i*pi*k*x)> then simply gives the length of the orthogonal projection of f onto the space spanned by e^(2*i*pi*k*x). Every nice function being expressible as a Fourier series then simply means that they form a basis (or Schauder basis - to be more precise - as we need infinite sums) and the coefficients in the Fourier series are simply the coordinates of f with respect to that basis.


On a side note, there are some glaring omissions from the immortals of mathematics: Grothendieck, Hilbert, Poincaré, Tarski, Artin, Kolmogorov, von Neumann, Erdős, Banach, ... and, if we want to add some still alive today, Serre, Deligne, Milnor, Szemerédi ...

Solutions:


WARNING SPOILER ALERT








Solution 1: We first break down the step function, as Grant did, into two integrals. We take the -1 out of the second integral so we only need to integrate once. The integral of e^(-n2piit) is e^(-n2piit)/-n2pii by basic u-substitution. SInce this is a definite integral, plug everything in, simply and apply e^pii=-1, we get [2(-1)^(-n)-(-1)^(-2n)-1]/-2npii. If n is odd, we get 2/npii, if n is even, we get 0.




Solution 2: Because we know c_n, and we know c_n is 0 if n is even, we only need to worry about the odd numbers. Now pair up n and -n, where n is odd. We get (and I hope you can read the syntax)


[(2/npii)e^(2npiit)]-[(2/npii)e^(-2npiit)]


Which after some arranging and factoring is


(4/npi)[(e^2npit - e^-2piit)/2i]


And with Grants wonderful hint we can reduct this to


(4/npi)sin(n*2pit)


as desired.


Solution 3:I thought about a phase shift, which means adding pi/2 to the expression inside the sine, but that is trivial and doesn't accomplish anything (since the boundary conditions aren't filled). But you asked for cosine functions, and here they are.

If you take the fourier transform of both of those, I'd expect very different spectra. When reconstructing the image, if you the number of terms used, I'd expect the first one will reconstruct as a perfect circle but the latter would be distorted.

Brilliant. Now please also make a video which shows why rotations are important in the first place. Points are:

(a) adding two rotations of same frequency gives a rotation of same frequency (easy to show with complex exp, but people should actually visualize it)
(b) differentiating a rotation gives another rotation of same frequency (which comes from (a) itself)
(c) with (a) and (b) we can show that analyzing a linear system with a bunch differentials and additions is easier when you split signals into a combination of rotations.
